channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Meta agrees to pay Trump $25 million to settle lawsuit over Facebook and Instagram suspensions
item.description: Meta agreed to pay President Trump $25 million to settle a 2021 federal lawsuit alleging First Amendment violations after his suspension from Facebook and Instagram in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack.
item.content:encoded:
Meta agreed to pay President Trump $25 million to settle a 2021 federal lawsuit alleging First Amendment violations after his suspension from Facebook and Instagram in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack.

(Image credit: Photo Illustration by Thomas Fuller)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: What would RFK Jr. mean to HHS?
item.description:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced senators today in a contentious confirmation hearing to serve as Health and Human Services Secretary under President Trump. He's a former Democrat — turned independent presidential candidate — turned Trump loyalist.

He's also someone who has pushed vaccine misinformation, something he was repeatedly questioned about during his confirmation hearing on Wednesday.

HHS is a massive system that oversees everything from the Food and Drug Administration to vaccine funding to the Affordable Care Act. What do we know about how Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. would run it?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced senators today in a contentious confirmation hearing to serve as Health and Human Services Secretary under President Trump. He's a former Democrat — turned independent presidential candidate — turned Trump loyalist.

He's also someone who has pushed vaccine misinformation, something he was repeatedly questioned about during his confirmation hearing on Wednesday.

HHS is a massive system that oversees everything from the Food and Drug Administration to vaccine funding to the Affordable Care Act. What do we know about how Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. would run it?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

(Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)

item.title: Trump orders Education, Labor and other departments to enhance school choice
item.description: The president directed several departments to submit plans for using federal funds to expand school choice.
item.content:encoded:
The president directed several departments to submit plans for using federal funds to expand school choice.

(Image credit: Jim Watson)
item.dc:creator: Jonaki Mehta

item.title: Trump's pick for Commerce Secretary is Howard Lutnick. Here's what to know
item.description: The billionaire Wall Street CEO fielded questions about tariffs, China's AI progress, broadband access, allegiance to Trump and the revival of American mining and semiconductor production.
item.content:encoded:
The billionaire Wall Street CEO fielded questions about tariffs, China's AI progress, broadband access, allegiance to Trump and the revival of American mining and semiconductor production.

(Image credit: Rod Lamkey)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Photos: Celebrations commence the Year of the Snake
item.description: For many, the Lunar New Year is a time to reflect on people they have lost. But it's also a time to set intentions and welcome the new energy of the future.
item.content:encoded:
For many, the Lunar New Year is a time to reflect on people they have lost. But it's also a time to set intentions and welcome the new energy of the future.

(Image credit: Greg Baker/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Manuela López Restrepo

item.title: Trump ends extension of temporary protected status for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan migrants
item.description: The move to revoke the extension of temporary protected status would make hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans eligible for deportation.
item.content:encoded:
The move to revoke the extension of temporary protected status would make hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans eligible for deportation.

(Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Garsd

item.title: Trump's Mideast envoy visits Gaza before meeting with Netanyahu
item.description: Steve Witkoff helped negotiate the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. His visit to Gaza on Wednesday was the first by a senior U.S. official in more than a decade.
item.content:encoded:
Steve Witkoff helped negotiate the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. His visit to Gaza on Wednesday was the first by a senior U.S. official in more than a decade.

(Image credit: Hasan Eslayeh)
item.dc:creator: Kat Lonsdorf

item.title: Hegseth strips Milley of his security detail, orders investigation into his conduct
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered an investigation into retired general Mark Milley — who often clashed with President Trump — and determine whether he should be reduced in rank.
item.content:encoded:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered an investigation into retired general Mark Milley — who often clashed with President Trump — and determine whether he should be reduced in rank.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: Ahmed al-Sharaa, who toppled Assad, is named Syria's interim president
item.description: Sharaa was already de facto head of Syria's government ever since a coalition of rebel fighters swept through most of Syria and ousted Assad's regime.
item.content:encoded:
Sharaa was already de facto head of Syria's government ever since a coalition of rebel fighters swept through most of Syria and ousted Assad's regime.

(Image credit: Ali Haj Suleiman)
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: New York becomes the first state to close schools for Lunar New Year
item.description: It's the first time New York students will have the day off for the Lunar New Year since a new state law was signed in 2023. In 2024, the holiday fell on a Saturday.
item.content:encoded:
It's the first time New York students will have the day off for the Lunar New Year since a new state law was signed in 2023. In 2024, the holiday fell on a Saturday.

(Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez
